awd_titl_txt: Lighting Up the Cosmic Web: Probing Galaxy Formation and the Surrounding Gas Reservoir Using Giant Lyman-alpha Nebulae
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding how galaxies and black holes grow out of and impact the larger cosmic environment is the underlying goal of much of extragalactic astronomy. The aim of this proposed project is to use giant gaseous nebulae as a window into the galaxy formation process, building an efficient method for finding these systems and then studying both the forming galaxy properties and the physical conditions in the surrounding intergalactic gas. In doing so, the program will leverage both the power of the Big Data era as well as the latest astronomical instruments to provide a synthesized view of galaxy formation and black hole growth in action during the first few billion years of cosmic time. The project will provide research experiences for two undergraduates per year at a Hispanic serving institution. It will also develop training packages that will help inspire underrepresented students to realize their potential in the sciences. These packages will be used in the classroom as well as in public outreach. The EPSCoR program is helping to fund this project.

The project will use existing and future big data sets of broad band imaging to identify giant Ly-alpha emitting clouds that are associated with galaxy forming regions. Using existing high-resolution images and catalogs, the project will then take a census of the galaxy population around these clouds. The team will apply for telescope time to obtain spatially resolved spectroscopy of the clouds to map out the kinematics and physical conditions within the diffuse gas clouds. The project will support graduate students and undergraduate students from a Hispanic serving institution. It will also develop "growth mindset training packages" for use in introductory astronomy courses (impacting over 500 students over three years) and in public observing events (reaching over 3000 people over three years). The project is being co-funded by the EPSCoR program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
"Lyman-alpha blobs" are giant clouds of glowing Hydrogen gas in the distant universe.  These rare objects act like signposts of forming galaxy clusters, regions that will one day become the most crowded "galaxy cities" within the larger cosmic landscape. While Lyman-alpha blobs have been found in smaller numbers using traditional imaging surveys in the past, the aim of this progam was to develop a machine learning algorithm capable of finding them in both existing and upcoming Big Datasets, to study both the motions and physical conditions within these glowing nebulae, and to investigate the properties of galaxies forming in their shadows. Our program has generated a number of outcomes:
  • Using a two-stage machine learning approach (an ensemble algorithm combined with a convolutional neural network), this program has developed a final catalog of Lyman-alpha nebula candidates that can now be followed up observationally using large telescopes.
  • It has been known for decades that galaxies in galaxy clusters in the local universe show very different properties (mass in stars, colors, rates of forming stars) as compared to galaxies that live out in the cosmic "countryside."  However, when and how these differences first started to appear has remained an area of active research. Given that Lyman-alpha nebulae can act as tracers of regions that will one day become massive galaxy clusters, this work has provided a window into how galaxies start to be transformed when they move to the "big city."  Using Hubble Space Telescope imaging, spectroscopy, and catalogs, we found that galaxies within Lyman-alpha nebulae are brighter with higher stellar masses and star formation rates than galaxies in the surroundings at the same epoch of the universe's history. 
  • At the same time, we also found that the properties of individual galaxies with strong emission from Hydrogen (Lyman-alpha emitting galaxies) do not appear to depend on whether they reside near or far from the overdense environments of Lyman-alpha nebulae.
  • Using spectroscopic data on Lyman-alpha nebulae in the distant universe, we found evidence for chaotic gas motions and put spatially resolved constraints on the density, metallicity, and incident ionizing flux within a Lyman-alpha nebula. We also found support for the idea that these nebulae can be powered by a central supermassive black hole that is either highly dust-obscured or that has ramped down in activity over the past 50,000-100,000 years, leaving behind a glowing nebula as an ionization echo.
  • We have used spectroscopy of Lyman-alpha nebulae around faded supermassive black holes in the local universe to reveal the properties (metallicities, densities, temperatures) within these glowing gas clouds. Our findings suggest that these glowing nebulae have relatively typical densities and temperatures, but intriguingly low gas metallicities.
  • Finally, dust is a key component of galaxies that affects measurements of other important properties such as star formation rates, stellar masses, and stellar ages. Our program included a side investigation into a method for determining how much dust is absorbing the light we are trying to observe from galaxies. We showed that using three emission lines widely separated in wavelength, we can make an improved estimate of the impact of dust and therefore do a better job of correcting for it in our galaxy observations.
The program has also had a Broader Impact by studying the learning mindsets of students in introductory astronomy classes and developing materials to help students cultivate a beneficial growth-oriented mindset about learning astronomy, i.e., the belief that one can get better at astronomy given time and effort.  Using student surveys over several years, we found that while university students say they believe in a growth mindset, a belief that was quite stable over time, they don't necessary know how to channel that belief to their own benefit when faced with normal learning challenges. These results motivate interventions that help students internalize that good learning will not feel easy and develop more effective learning skills. Our program also developed a set of "story packages" aimed at introductory classes and outreach events to highlight stories of a diverse range of scientists from a "growth mindset" perspective, i.e., focusing on how they overcame obstacles, made scientific contributions, and grew intellectually through effort and persistence.
